`attrs` is a Python library for creating classes with concise, declarative syntax for the initialization of attributes. It is designed to be a simple and easy-to-use alternative to `__init__` methods, and provides additional functionality such as automatic generation of comparison and representation methods.

Here is an example of how to use `attrs` to create a class:
```
import attr

@attr.s
class Person:
    name = attr.ib()
    age = attr.ib()

p = Person("Alice", 30)
print(p)
```
This creates a class `Person` with two attributes `name` and `age` which can be accessed like any other class attribute and is initialized on object creation.

You can also validate the inputs passed to attributes by providing a validator function.
```
import attr

@attr.s
class Person:
    name = attr.ib(validator=attr.validators.instance_of(str))
    age = attr.ib(validator=attr.validators.instance_of(int))

p = Person("Alice", 30) #this is valid
p = Person(30, 30) #this will throw an error as name is not string
```
It also provides options to customize the behaviour of attributes like default value, conversion function, etc.
